importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the announcement regarding Admiral Alvin Holsey's retirement, which follows recent military actions in the Caribbean and Venezuela.
The date Admiral Holsey was sworn in as commander of US Southern Command.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period during which Admiral Holsey served as commander of US Southern Command, including the tenure during which tensions with Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth arose and culminated in his retirement announcement.

keyTakeAways: Admiral Alvin Holsey is retiring from the US Navy on December 12, 2025, one year after being sworn in as commander of US Southern Command.
The retirement follows tensions between Holsey and Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth over the pace and legality of military operations in the Caribbean, especially drug interdiction efforts.
The US military conducted its fifth known strike on a drug-trafficking boat off Venezuela’s coast in late October 2025, killing six people.
President Donald Trump publicly authorized the CIA to operate inside Venezuela to disrupt drug and migrant flows, adding political context to the military actions.
US Air Force B-52 bombers flew off Venezuela’s coast for over four hours, indicating escalation of operations in the region.
Southern Command expressed concern about the legality of these operations, while Defense Secretary Hegseth criticized Holsey for insufficient operational aggression.
Holsey offered to resign during a meeting at the Pentagon on October 6, 2025, but the resignation was deferred and only officially announced a week later.
The Pentagon denied that Holsey expressed reservations about the counter-narcotic mission, though internal sources indicate otherwise.
Holsey has 37 years of military service, including roles as commander of Carrier Strike Group One and Military Deputy Commander at Southern Command.
Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth has replaced multiple senior military officials since taking office, signaling a broader shift in military leadership and strategy.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Admiral Alvin Holsey, who led US Southern Command from November 2024 to his retirement on December 12, 2025, is stepping down amid tensions with Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth over the pace and legality of military operations targeting drug traffickers in the Caribbean. The article highlights a series of recent US military actions, including a fifth known strike on a drug-trafficking boat off Venezuela’s coast, killing six people, and the deployment of B-52 bombers in the region. These actions are further supported by President Donald Trump’s public authorization of CIA operations in Venezuela to curb drug and migrant flows. While Pentagon officials deny Holsey raised legal concerns, internal sources suggest he believed operations were too slow and lacked transparency, leading to a formal resignation offer at a Pentagon meeting on October 6, 2025, which was deferred. Holsey, with 37 years of military service, emphasized the enduring contributions of the SOUTHCOM team and the mission's role in defending national interests. His departure marks a leadership transition within a command facing growing scrutiny over the legality and scope of its counter-narcotics operations.
title: Commander Overseeing US Forces in the Caribbean to Retire One Year into Tenure
